name: Massimo Bottura
bio: Massimo Bottura is an Italian chef and restaurateur. He is the owner of Osteria Francescana, a three-Michelin-starred restaurant in Modena, Italy. Massimo is known for his innovative and avant-garde approach to Italian cuisine, which he calls 'tradition in evolution.'

recipes.cooking_method: 1. Cook spaghetti according to package instructions. 2. While spaghetti is cooking, cook diced pancetta in a skillet until crispy. 3. In a bowl, whisk together egg yolks, Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, and black pepper. 4. Drain spaghetti and add to the skillet with the pancetta. 5. Remove skillet from heat and add egg yolk mixture. Toss until pasta is coated. Serve immediately.

1. Preheat oven to 500°F. 2. Roll out pizza dough to desired shape and thickness. 3. Spread tomato sauce over dough, leaving a 1-inch border around the edges. 4. Add slices of fresh mozzarella cheese on top of the sauce. 5. Place basil leaves on top of cheese. 6. Drizzle olive oil over pizza. 7. Bake in preheated oven for 8-10 minutes or until crust is golden brown and cheese is melted. Serve hot.

1. In a large saucepan, bring chicken broth to a simmer. 2. In a separate saucepan, toast Arborio rice over medium heat until lightly golden. 3. Add white wine to the rice and cook until evaporated. 4. Add a ladleful of simmering broth to the rice and stir until absorbed. 5. Continue adding broth, one ladleful at a time, stirring constantly, until rice is tender and creamy. 6. In a small bowl, dissolve saffron threads in a ladleful of hot broth. Add to the risotto and stir until combined. 7. Remove risotto from heat and stir in Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese. Serve immediately.

1. Cook pasta according to package instructions. Drain and set aside.
2. In a food processor, combine basil, Parmesan, olive oil, pine nuts, garlic, salt, and pepper. Pulse until smooth.
3. Preheat oven to 400°F. Place cherry tomatoes on a baking sheet and drizzle with olive oil. Sprinkle with salt and pepper. Toss to coat. Roast for 20 minutes, until tomatoes are slightly charred and wrinkled.
4. Toss pasta with pesto and roasted tomatoes. Serve hot.

name: Carlo Cracco
bio: Carlo Cracco is an Italian chef and television personality. He is the owner of Ristorante Cracco, a two-Michelin-starred restaurant in Milan, Italy. Carlo is known for his creative and contemporary Italian cuisine, which combines traditional ingredients with modern techniques.

recipes.cooking_method: 1. Preheat the oven to 350°F. 2. Cut the bread into bite-size pieces and spread them out on a baking sheet. 3. Bake the bread in the oven for about 10 minutes until it's crisp and slightly golden. 4. Cut the tomatoes and cucumber into bite-size pieces and thinly slice the red onion. 5. In a large bowl, combine the bread, tomatoes, cucumber, red onion, and torn basil leaves. 6. Drizzle the salad with red wine vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil, and toss to coat. 7. Let the salad sit for about 15-20 minutes before serving to allow the bread to soak up the dressing.

1. Cook the potatoes until they're soft and tender, and then mash them in a large bowl. 2. Add the flour and egg to the bowl with the mashed potatoes and mix until the dough comes together. 3. Roll the dough into long ropes and cut them into small pieces to make the gnocchi. 4. Bring a pot of salted water to a boil and cook the gnocchi until they float to the surface. 5. In a separate pan, heat up the tomato sauce. 6. When the gnocchi are cooked, remove them from the water with a slotted spoon and add them to the tomato sauce. 7. Mix the gnocchi and sauce together and add in small pieces of mozzarella cheese. 8. Transfer everything to a baking dish, top with grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese and basil leaves. 9. Bake in the oven at 350°F for 15-20 minutes until the cheese is melted and bubbly.

1. In a large pot, sauté chopped onion, carrots, celery, and garlic until soft. 2. Add ground beef and cook until browned. 3. Pour in canned tomatoes and red wine, and let it simmer for 10-15 minutes. 4. Add beef stock and bay leaves, and let it simmer for 1-2 hours until the sauce has thickened. 5. Serve with your choice of pasta and grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese.

1. Cook the pasta according to package instructions until al dente. Drain and rinse under cold water.
2. In a food processor, pulse the basil, Parmesan, olive oil, pine nuts, garlic, salt, and pepper until smooth.
3. In a large bowl, toss the pasta with the pesto until well coated. Add the cherry tomatoes, black olives, and parsley, and toss to combine.
4. Chill the pasta salad for at least 1 hour before serving.

Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Cook linguine according to package instructions until al dente. Meanwhile, in a large skillet, heat the olive oil over medium heat. Add garlic and red pepper flakes and cook until fragrant, about 30 seconds. Add white wine and clams, and cover the skillet. Cook until the clams open, about 6-8 minutes. Discard any clams that do not open. Add butter to the skillet and stir until melted. Drain the linguine and add it to the skillet. Toss well and sprinkle with parsley. Serve hot.

name: Roberto Santini
bio: Nadia Santini is an Italian chef and restaurateur. She is the owner of Dal Pescatore, a three-Michelin-starred restaurant in Canneto sull'Oglio, Italy. Nadia is known for her traditional and rustic Italian cuisine, which she learned from her mother and grandmother.

recipes.cooking_method: 1. Preheat oven to 375°F. 2. Cook lasagna noodles in salted boiling water. 3. In a separate pan, brown ground beef with onion and garlic. 4. Add tomato sauce to the beef mixture. 5. In a separate bowl, mix ricotta cheese, mozzarella cheese, and parmesan cheese. 6. In a 9x13 inch baking dish, layer noodles, meat sauce, and cheese mixture. 7. Repeat layers, ending with cheese mixture on top. 8. Top with fresh basil leaves. 9. Bake for 25-30 minutes or until cheese is melted and bubbly. Serve hot.

1. Separate the egg yolks from the whites. 2. Beat the egg yolks with sugar until pale and creamy. 3. Add the mascarpone cheese and mix until smooth. 4. Beat the egg whites until stiff peaks form, and fold them into the mascarpone mixture. 5. Dip the ladyfingers into the espresso and place them at the bottom of a dish. 6. Pour half of the mascarpone mixture on top of the ladyfingers. 7. Repeat with another layer of espresso-dipped ladyfingers and mascarpone mixture. 8. Sprinkle cocoa powder on top. 9. Refrigerate for at least 4 hours before serving.

1. In a food processor, combine basil leaves, garlic, pine nuts, Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese, pecorino cheese and a pinch of salt. Pulse until finely chopped. 2. With the food processor running, slowly drizzle in the olive oil until the pesto is smooth and well combined. 3. Taste and adjust seasoning if necessary. 4. Use the pesto immediately, or store it in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to a week.

name: Gualtiero Marchesi
bio: Gualtiero Marchesi was an Italian chef and restaurateur. He was the first Italian chef to be awarded three Michelin stars, and he was known for his innovative and artistic approach to Italian cuisine. Gualtiero passed away in 2017, but his legacy lives on in the world of Italian gastronomy.

recipes.cooking_method: 1. Preheat oven to 375°F. Cook the lasagna noodles according to package directions. 2. Meanwhile, in a large skillet, heat olive oil over medium heat. Add ground beef and cook until browned. 3. Add onion, carrots, and celery and cook until vegetables are softened. 4. Add tomato paste and cook for a minute. 5. Add crushed tomatoes and beef broth and bring to a simmer. 6. Season with salt and pepper to taste. 7. In a separate bowl, whisk together ricotta cheese and eggs until smooth. 8. In a 9x13 inch baking dish, spread a layer of meat sauce. Add a layer of lasagna noodles, then spread a layer of ricotta mixture, and sprinkle with parmesan cheese. 9. Repeat layering with remaining ingredients, ending with a layer of meat sauce on top. 10. Sprinkle mozzarella cheese on top. 11. Cover with foil and bake for 25 minutes. 12. Remove foil and bake for another 25 minutes until cheese is golden brown and bubbly. 13. Let lasagna cool for a few minutes before serving.

1. Cook pasta in salted boiling water until al dente. 2. Meanwhile, prepare the pesto sauce. In a food processor or blender, combine fresh basil leaves, garlic, pine nuts, and Parmesan cheese. Pulse until finely chopped. 3. Gradually add olive oil while pulsing until the sauce is smooth. 4. Season with salt to taste. 5. Drain pasta and return to the pot. 6. Add the pesto sauce and toss until pasta is coated evenly. 7. Serve hot.

1. In a food processor, pulse the basil, garlic, and pine nuts until coarsely chopped. 2. With the processor running, slowly add the olive oil until the mixture is smooth. 3. Add the Parmesan cheese and pulse until just combined. 4. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

1. Cook the potatoes until they're soft and tender, and then mash them in a large bowl. 2. Add the flour and egg to the bowl with the mashed potatoes and mix until the dough comes together. 3. Roll the dough into long ropes and cut them into small pieces to make the gnocchi. 4. Bring a pot of salted water to a boil and cook the gnocchi until they float to the surface. 5. In a separate pan, heat up the tomato sauce. 6. When the gnocchi are cooked, remove them from the water with a slotted spoon and add them to the tomato sauce. 7. Mix the gnocchi and sauce together and add in small pieces of mozzarella cheese. 8. Transfer everything to a baking dish, top with grated Parmigiano-Reggiano cheese and basil leaves. 9. Bake in the oven at 350°F for 15-20 minutes until the cheese is melted and bubbly.

name: Antonio Cannavacciuolo
bio: Antonio Cannavacciuolo is an Italian chef and television personality. He is the owner of Villa Crespi, a two-Michelin-starred restaurant in Orta San Giulio, Italy. Antonio is known for his modern and creative approach to Italian cuisine, which emphasizes the flavors and traditions of his native region of Campania.

ingredients: 1 can (28 oz) whole tomatoes, drained and crushed
gremolata (lemon zest, garlic, parsley) for serving
recipes.cooking_method: 1. Preheat the oven to 350°F. Season the veal shanks with salt and pepper and coat in flour. 2. Heat butter in a large dutch oven over medium heat. Add the veal shanks and cook until browned on both sides. Remove from the pot and set aside. 3. Add onion, carrot, and celery to the pot and sauté until softened. Add garlic and cook for another minute. 4. Deglaze the pot with white wine, scraping any browned bits from the bottom. Add tomatoes, broth, bay leaf, salt, and pepper. Bring to a simmer. 5. Return the veal shanks to the pot and spoon some of the sauce over them. Cover and transfer to the oven. Bake for about 2 hours, until the meat is very tender. 6. Serve hot, garnished with gremolata.

cooking_method: Boil the potatoes in a large pot of salted water until tender, about 25 minutes. Drain the potatoes and let cool.
Peel the potatoes and pass them through a potato ricer or food mill.
Combine the mashed potatoes with the flour, egg, Parmesan cheese, nutmeg, salt, and pepper. Mix until a dough forms.
Divide the dough into 4 equal parts and roll each part into a long rope, about 3/4-inch thick.
Cut the ropes into 1-inch pieces and press each piece with a fork to create ridges.
Bring a large pot of salted water to a boil. Add the gnocchi and cook until they float to the surface, about 2-3 minutes.
Drain the gnocchi and transfer to a baking dish. Top with tomato sauce, sliced mozzarella, and fresh basil leaves.
Bake in the oven at 375°F for 15-20 minutes, until the cheese is melted and bubbly.

recipes.cooking_method:
1. Cook pasta according to package directions. Reserve 1 cup pasta cooking water before draining. 
2. Meanwhile, heat olive oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat. Add onion and garlic and cook until onion is translucent. Add zucchini and continue to cook until zucchini is tender. 
3. Reduce heat to low and add cooked pasta, reserved pasta water, ricotta cheese, Parmesan cheese, and basil. Toss until everything is well combined and heated through. 
4. Season with salt and pepper to taste. Serve hot.

name: Enrico Crippa
bio: Enrico Crippa is an Italian chef and restaurateur. He is the owner of Piazza Duomo, a three-Michelin-starred restaurant in Alba, Italy. Enrico is known for his innovative and imaginative approach to Italian cuisine, which emphasizes the use of local and seasonal ingredients.

recipes.method:
1. Cook spaghetti in boiling water until al dente, according to package instructions. Reserve 1 cup of the pasta cooking water before draining. 
2. While spaghetti is cooking, heat a large skillet over medium heat. Add pancetta and cook until crispy. Add garlic and cook until fragrant. 
3. In a small bowl, whisk together Parmesan cheese and eggs. 
4. Add the cooked spaghetti to the skillet with pancetta and garlic. Pour in the egg mixture and toss everything together until the spaghetti is coated in the sauce. 
5. Add reserved pasta cooking water, 1/4 cup at a time, until desired consistency is achieved. 
6. Season with salt and pepper to taste.

recipes.cooking_method:
1. Cook the spaghetti according to package instructions until al dente.
2. While the spaghetti is cooking, heat a large skillet over medium heat and add a drizzle of olive oil. Add the pancetta or guanciale and cook until crispy and golden brown, about 6-8 minutes. Add the garlic and cook for 1-2 minutes.
3. In a small bowl, whisk together the egg yolks, egg, Pecorino Romano cheese, and black pepper.
4. Drain the spaghetti, reserving about 1/2 cup of the pasta water. Add the spaghetti to the skillet with the pancetta and garlic and toss well to combine.
5. Remove the skillet from the heat and pour in the egg and cheese mixture, tossing quickly to coat the spaghetti. If the pasta seems dry, add a bit of the reserved pasta water.
6. Serve immediately, garnished with additional Pecorino Romano cheese and black pepper, if desired.

1. Preheat oven to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C).
2. Bring a large pot of lightly salted water to a boil. Add ziti pasta, and cook until al dente, about 8 minutes; drain.
3. In a large skillet, brown onion and ground beef over medium heat. Add spaghetti sauce, and simmer 15 minutes.
4. Grease a 9x13 inch baking dish. Layer as follows: 1/2 of the ziti, Provolone cheese, sour cream, 1/2 sauce mixture, remaining ziti, mozzarella cheese and remaining sauce mixture. Top with grated Parmesan cheese.
5. Bake for 30 minutes in the preheated oven, or until cheeses are melted.

1. Preheat oven to 500°F. 2. Roll out pizza dough to desired shape and thickness. 3. Spread tomato sauce over dough, leaving a 1-inch border around the edges. 4. Add slices of fresh mozzarella cheese on top of the sauce. 5. Place basil leaves on top of cheese. 6. Drizzle olive oil over pizza. 7. Bake in preheated oven for 8-10 minutes or until crust is golden brown and cheese is melted. Serve hot.

1. Preheat the oven to 350°F. 2. Cut the bread into bite-size pieces and spread them out on a baking sheet. 3. Bake the bread in the oven for about 10 minutes until it's crisp and slightly golden. 4. Cut the tomatoes and cucumber into bite-size pieces and thinly slice the red onion. 5. In a large bowl, combine the bread, tomatoes, cucumber, red onion, and torn basil leaves. 6. Drizzle the salad with red wine vinegar and extra-virgin olive oil, and toss to coat. 7. Let the salad sit for about 15-20 minutes before serving to allow the bread to soak up the dressing.
